utterances: Now, when we look at influence, I'm reasonably certain that we can make a pretty compelling case that the protests made it very hard for Trump and the Republicans to pass their health care reform plan.
The Democrats claim victory for this.
Protesters were ecstatic, but it didn't make their lives better.
It didn't change policy in any way.
It was a defensive win.
It seems to me that keeping this up is a difficult thing logistically and emotionally, what we've seen so far in these first three months.
Is it likely to wane in the coming months?
If people just show up at demonstrations, then it gets fatiguing.
So do you go to the science march this week or the climate march next week?
If you go to both, then who's going to get your groceries on the weekend?
It is hard.
It is tiring.

But if the protests are seen as punctuation marks in a larger story of dissent in which people turn up at town meetings and ask questions about the funding of NIH, in which people run for office, in which people vote in state legislative elections, well then you can have a lot of impact and you can have sustained influence.
David Meyer is a professor of sociology at the University of California, Irvine and the author of ""The Politics Of Protest: Social Movements In America."" Professor Meyer, thanks a lot.
Thank you.
Now let's hear about the man The New Yorker magazine calls, quote, ""the thinking man's guitar hero,"" unquote.
Gary Lucas has played just about everywhere with just about everyone from Captain Beefheart to DJ Spooky to John Sebastian.
But Lucas is also a huge movie fan, and Rick Karr reports that the guitarist's career embraces both passions, music and movies.
Gary Lucas' best-known work may be his collaborations with the lead singer and songwriter Jeff Buckley.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""GRACE"")
(Singing) My fading voice sings of love, but she cries to the clicking of time, oh, time.
Movies were Lucas' first love as a kid growing up in Syracuse, N.Y., monster movies.
He screened them for neighbor kids in his parents' basement.
Eight-millimeter versions of classic Universal horror films such as ""Frankenstein"" and ""Dracula"" and ""The Mummy.
(SOUNDBITE OF FILM, ""THE MUMMY"")
(As Imhotep) A nameless grave.
The slaves were killed so that none should know.
The soldiers who killed them were also slain so no friend could creep to the desert with funeral offerings for my condemned spirit.
Movies had to compete with music after his father gave him a Fender Stratocaster as a bar mitzvah present.
Lucas went to Yale and started a horror film series there.
Movies took a backseat when he became Captain Beefheart's guitarist and manager.
In 1989, the Brooklyn Academy of Music commissioned Lucas to collaborate on a live score for a silent film.
He remembered stills he'd seen in a film magazine as a kid.
They came from a German expressionist film based on a Jewish legend called ""The Golem.
So I arranged for a private screening.
And I came out of that, like, this is the film for me.
This should be better known.
It's just an incredible film.
(SOUNDBITE OF GARY LUCAS' ""MUSIC FOR 'THE GOLEM' - MAIN TITLE - RABBI LOEW CONSULTS THE STAR - THE DECREE"")
Lucas performed the scored screenings around the world, and film music became a major focus of his career.

He's composed 11 live scores, including one for a Spanish-language version of ""Dracula"" and another for a silent Chinese melodrama called ""The Goddess."" Film archivist and curator Andrew Lampert says Lucas' love of cinema comes through in his music.
I think that Gary has a very sort of narrative style in his guitar playing.
You know, he doesn't just, like, drop in and do a solo.
There's a lot of structure to what he's doing.
It is, like, almost visual.
(SOUNDBITE OF GARY LUCAS' ""TOO MUCH JOHNSON"")
Lucas' most recent live score is for a 1938 silent slapstick comedy directed by Orson Welles.
The filmmaker planned for it to be projected between acts of a play he was directing, a revival of an 1890s farce called ""Too Much Johnson.
(SOUNDBITE OF GARY LUCAS' ""TOO MUCH JOHNSON"")
Welles abandoned the film before he finished editing it and the original footage was presumed lost until a work print was discovered in Italy about a decade ago.
Gary Lucas wrote the score the way he's written others, by watching the film again and again.
I look at the film with guitar in hand many, many times.
I get to know it intimately.
And I try various things and then try and time them to the sequences.
(SOUNDBITE OF GARY LUCAS' ""TOO MUCH JOHNSON"")
(SOUNDBITE OF ROGER WOOD, ""HERE WE GO, STEELERS"")
Nearly a quarter million Americans leave the armed forces every year, and for decades, many of them have gone back to college, thanks to the GI Bill.
Today's veterans are about to get an educational windfall.
A new GI Bill takes effect this summer.
That means qualifying vets can now get their full tuition at public universities covered plus stipends for housing and books.
And for the first time, those benefits can be transferred to spouses and children.
The new GI Bill has colleges scrambling to recruit veterans with the kind of intensity usually reserved for athletes.
Nancy Farghalli checks in with one school, San Diego State University.
Pardon the echo.
That's the first thing Nathaniel Donnelly says when he describes where we stand at San Diego State.
There's no furniture in the room.
But imagine in a month a couple of recliners, a few desks, and maybe an Xbox just for student veterans.
We are in an empty lounge.
And the veterans on campus really don't have a place to study or hang out, have lunch, watch TV.
So, this room here that will be finished really soon will provide an atmosphere where they can relax, recreate that camaraderie that they had in the military.
Donnelly spent eight years in the Marine Corps.
Now, he's a 32-year-old senior, and he works as the assistant veterans coordinator on campus.
More than 800 military vets are enrolled at San Diego State.
That's less than one percent of the student body.
But Donnelly expects the new GI Bill to increase the military population.
We expect those numbers to skyrocket for obvious reasons.
They are going to get paid a lot more to go to school.
They're not going to have to work full time and go to school full time.
So, they'll, you know, be able to spend time with their family.
They'll be able to provide for their family, as well as go to school at the same time.
And San Diego State wants to be the school of choice.
The city is home to the nation's largest military community.
Camp Pendleton is nearby.
Donnelly says the college is marketing to military personnel.
There is an admission Web site for vets, priority for classes, and gone is the informational kiosk.
Now, they have an office.
(Soundbite of phone ringing)
San Diego State Veteran Center.
Junior Jay Birth is a former Marine.
Now, he works part-time at the veterans center, explaining the GI Bill and other programs.
If one of you were a veteran and you were disabled, then the state of California has a benefit calledâ€¦
Terry Howell is the managing editor of Military.com.
He says the expanded GI Bill will push other schools to follow San Diego Stat's lead.
Whenever you increase a government fund to help somebody go to school, that student is going to be more attractive to schools.
But for the most part, I believe it really is just that true desire to serve those who have sacrificed and served their nation.
Dr. James Kitchen says that's a generational change in attitude.
He is vice president of student affairs at San Diego State and a Vietnam vet.
When I came home from the war, we weren't embraced like the men and women are today, and I don't consider that - I'm not jealous about it, it's just a reality of life.
And I was bitter for many, many, many years.
But at the same time, I look at the needs of these young men and women coming out of Afghanistan, out of Iraq.
I just woke up one day and said, you know what?
These young men and women need all the help they can get and all the support they can get.
But Kitchen says the college has a lot of homework to do when it comes to embracing the unique challenges of vets.
You come from a situation where you have been in war.
There may be a disability, there may not be.
There may be counseling and psychological needs, there may not be.
The more you have, the more difficult it's going to be on the staff to accommodate these young men and women.
On the other hand, we'll figure out a way to make it work.
The university is kicking off a fundraising campaign for scholarships.
Some of the money will also fund perks like that military student lounge and converting a frat house to apartments for vets.
Nancy Farghalli, NPR News.
(Soundbite of music)
From Oshkosh, now, to a city that native son Mr. Rogers called one of the biggest small towns in America, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.
Pittsburgh is starting a two-month-long birthday party today.
It was founded 250 years ago by a general named John Forbes and his sidekick, a young colonel named George Washington.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
(Singing) Pittsburgh town is a smoky old town, Pittsburgh.
By the 1900s, industrialists made this the nation's capital of iron, steel, and glass production.
In 1952, long before she was mothering the Partridge family, actress Shirley Jones got her start there by winning the Ms. Pittsburgh pageant.
